Dated Hew Delhi, 6th January, 1931 0 Received 6th January, 1931, 1.15 p e m. Your Political Secretary J s letter So.7166/30, 5th November. Visa fees. Government of India concur in terms of proposed reply.Gold Frs.l Gold Frs.! The Under-f ^o. T 10647/5904/376 In any further communication on this subject, please quote and address— but to— “ The Under-Secretary of State.” Foreign Office, London, S.W.l. not to any per non by name, not to any per non by name, S.W.l. r\ 13th October, 1930 Sir I am directed by Mr. Secretary Henderson to transmit to you herewith a cony of a despatch from His v Majesty's Minister in Tehran regarding the visa\fees to be charged to natives of Oman, Muscat and Koweit for the purpose of proceeding to British territory. 2. Subject to Mr. Secretary Benn*s concurrence Mr. Henderson proposes to reply that the standard fees Gold Frs.l. of one and ten gold francs respectively for transit and Gold Frs.10. ordinary visas should be levied. I am to add that Major Barrett will by now have received the revised chapter 22 of General Instructions to Consular Officers in the annex of which the Sultanate of Oman and Muscat and Koweit now appear. I am. Sir, Your obedient Servant The Under-Secretary of State India Office ENCLOSURE IN LETTER I 1-iO 43 2 3 OCT 1330 \_ ANi>i Ho. 436. 1 Oulhek. > : c’i ■ 9th Septeisbepy 1930* ' Sir* I have the honour to transmit to you -herewith a copy of despatch No. 63 dated the 1st Instant, addressed to me by His Majesty's Consul • »•©,ie.• Ci .c -n jo^asan, on the subject of the correct visa i:ees to be charged on the passports of natives of the State of Oman and Ituscat, and of natives of Kuirelt. In thc absence of special instructions on this subject, I presume that the fees to be charged should be the standard fees of one and ten gold francs respectively for a transit and ordinary visa* 3 * A <*°py of this despatch is being sent to His Majesty's Consul General, Meshed. I have the honour to be with the highest respect. Sir, Your most obedient, humble Servant, (Signed) R. h. Clive. The Eight Honourable Arthur Henderson, H.F., The Foreign Office.British Consulate G-eneral, No. 63 Meshed. Meshed. September 1, 1930. sir, I have the honour to enquire whether there is tny record in the archives of the Legation of the correct fees to he charged to natives of the State of Oman and Muscat for ordinary diu transit tf&es for British territory. The State of Oman and Muscat does not appear in the annex to Chapter XXII of the Consular General Instructions as under British protection, nor, on the other hand does it figure in the Summary Visa Regulations or, so far as I hcive been able to trace, in any Foreign Office Circular relating to visaa. I h ve therefore been at a loss in dealing with applications I for visas to India made by natives of the :>tate of Om; n and Muscat to whom, as you are aware, Meshed is centre a A pilgrimage If, in the absence of ;,ny papers on the subject! you consider it desirable to iubmit the matter to th~ < secretary of ^>tate you may be uisposea to include a reference to natives of Koweit mention of whom in thi> connexion appears to be equally ; instructions. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: Coll 27/2 ‘Passports. Persian Gulf. Visa fees for natives of Oman, Muscat and Koweit proceeding to British Territory’

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 12; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains papers regarding visa fees to be charged to natives of Oman and Muscat, and of Koweit [Kuwait], for proceeding to British territory.The papers mostly consist of correspondence between the following: the India Office; the Foreign Office; HM Minister, Tehran (Robert Henry Clive); HM Consul General, Meshed (Cyril Charles Johnson Barrett); and the Government of India Foreign and Political Department.The file includes a divider, which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.

name.namePart: Government of India, Foreign and Political Department
